Label: 'ajar
Scope Note: Tunisian woman's head-veil, often square, worn over the head.

Label: Ebauche
Scope Note: Term used to describe a watch movement which could be purchased from a supplier in various states of completion ranging from simple plates, pillars and balance-cock etc to a completely finished watch movement. Generally the ebauches were supplied with unfinished pivots and without any components of the escapement. Ebauches were purchased by "watchmakers" to be finished by skilled watchmakers ready for dialling and casing up for retail.

Label: adhesive sample
Scope Note: The names of the constituents should be entered in the Materials field.

Label: adinkra-stamp
Scope Note: Adinkra are the textiles made by the Ashanti people of Ghana.

Label: adire
Scope Note: The term refers to indigo resist-dyed cloths made by the Yoruba people of Nigeria. Adire (translated as 'tie and dye') originally referred to simple indigo tie-dyed textiles on hand-woven cloth. The name is now applied more generally to refer to indigo-dyed cloth produced by the Yoruba people using a variety of resist-dyed techniques which evolved during the 20th century with the increase in imported cotton shirting. These cloths use starch resist-dyed techniques such as hand-painting (known as adire eleko) and stencilling, as well as stitch resist-dyed, tie-dyed and fold resist-dyed techniques. Some of these techniques may be used in combination on a single cloth.

Label: adorno
Scope Note: Applied or inserted relief adornment to a variety of object types, most often vessels and figures. Also add the object type when using if known.

Label: advertisement
Scope Note: The term is added as an additional Object Name to records for objects which arwe used for advertising purposes, e.g. tokens, coins, posters, etc.

Label: aegis
Scope Note: For the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the term refers to a ritual fitting, usually Hathor-headed or female-headed, held in the hand. For the Department of Greece and Rome, it refers to a Gorgon's head worn on the breast.

Label: aeolipile
Scope Note: An alternative name for these is sphero-conical vessels. The function of this very distinctive class of container has attracted many different opinions since the early nineteenth century. They have been interpreted as containers for mercury, fire-blowers (aeolipiles), grenades for containing Greek fire, flasks for containing fizzy alcohol or other liquids, holy water bottles or even lamps, loom-weights or decorative finials used in architecture. They have a very wide distribution stretching from Spain to Central Asia, date between the twelfth and thirteenth centuries, and were made in many different workshops. Whereas most are made of high-fired pottery, some were made of metal and glass. For more information, see: R. Ettinghausen, “The uses of sphero-conical vessels in the Muslim East”, ‘Journal of Near Eastern Studies’, 24/3 (July 1965), pp.218-229.

Label: aerophone
Scope Note: This is a general term for a musical instrument which produces a sound by a vibrating column of air. Wind instruments form the main sub-category.

Label: aes rude
Scope Note: Unworked lump of copper alloy used as currency.

Label: afena
Scope Note: The term refers to a sword of the Ashanti peoples - Ghana.

Label: ageng
Scope Note: The largest gong of the gamelan.

Label: agricultural equipment
Scope Note: See also GATHERING EQUIPMENT.

Label: agriculture/subsistence
Scope Note: Do not use this term as an Object Name.

Label: ahuayo
Scope Note: The term ahuayo (meaning 'woven cloth') refers to a woven cloth from the Andes, which can be used as a baby-carrier,a woman or a man's carrying cloth, a woman's mantle, a ceremonial altar, etc. and the corresponding Object Names should be entered in addition to 'ahuayo'. Strictly speaking, the ahuayo appeared in Colonial times as an adaptation of the former lliqlla (lliclla) garment.

Label: aksu
Scope Note: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' South America collections this term refers to a cloth frequently used as a garment.

Label: album
Scope Note: This term should be multiple-keyworded with DRAWING or PRINT, painting as appropriate. See also the Narrow Terms.

Label: alcohol equipment
Scope Note: The term includes all objects relating to either the production or consumption of alcoholic drinks. Generally, Greek and Roman vessels and Oriental ritual vessels have been excluded from this category. Objects involved in the preparation or consumption of punch have been included.

Label: alphabet
Scope Note: The term covers individual letters and sequences of letters.

Label: angavastrum
Scope Note: An Indian term for a shoulder mantle worn during a religious ritual.

Label: animal equipment
Scope Note: The term includes all objects associated with animals apart from HUNTING EQUIPMENT.

Label: animal/vegetal remains
Scope Note: The term does not include human remains, see separate term.

Label: ant-nose money
Scope Note: Small cast bronze coins of ancient China with inscriptions that resemble faces.

Label: architectural drawing
Scope Note: The term should be used for drawings which show elevations, sections, groundplans, etc., and that are measured or would be functional to architects. Drawings of architectural features that are integral to a building, such as fire-places or stair-cases, could also be given this object name. Ornamental or free-standing features may not be included in this category.

Label: architectural fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name ARCHITECTURE or its Narrow Terms.

Label: architecture
Scope Note: The term includes HYDRAULIC EQUIPMENT, e.g. DRAIN, and all objects forming a structural part of buildings or constructions.

Label: arkilla kerka
Scope Note: The term refers to wool and cotton bed-screens which are suspended along and over the alcove or bed, forming also a mosquito protection by adding another piece of cloth to it. The Arkilla kerka are a prestigious and an essential component of the bride’s trousseau in the Fulbe society and have an extremely important social and symbolic significance.

Label: arkilla munga
Scope Note: The term refers to wool and cotton bed-screens which are suspended along and over the alcove or bed. They are prestigious and important components of the bride’s trousseau in the Songoy society.

Label: arm-band
Scope Note: See also armlet, arm-ring, bangle and bracelet.

Label: arm-ring
Scope Note: See also arm-band, armlet, bangle and bracelet.

Label: arm-shaped vessel
Scope Note: Vessels, with a religious or ritual function, found in Cyprus, Anatolia and the Levant, in the Late Bronze Age period.

Label: arm-shield
Scope Note: The term refers to a narrow device worn on the arm and designed to ward off blows rather than protect the whole body.

Label: arm-sling
Scope Note: This term is restricted to garments.

Label: armature
Scope Note: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a a mount sometimes used to protect glass or porcelain.

Label: armlet
Scope Note: See also arm-band, arm-ring, bangle and bracelet.

Label: arms equipment
Scope Note: This category is mainly for equipment associated with arms and armour, but this term can be used in its own right.

Label: arms/armour
Scope Note: For associated equipment, see ARMS EQUIPMENT.

Label: arrow-head
Scope Note: This term is only entered as an Object Name for arrow heads found on their own. See also records with Object Name 'arrow'.

Label: art/writing equipment
Scope Note: Terms beginning 'paint' may refer to house-painting.

Label: artefact
Scope Note: This term refers to worked objects of uncertain function. See also 'band'.

Label: artist book
Scope Note: The term refers to 'books' created by artists.

Label: assignat
Scope Note: Eighteenth Century French paper money.

Label: astragalus
Scope Note: The term should be used in the context of a game; otherwise HUMAN REMAINS should be used.

Label: astrolabic quadrant
Scope Note: A quadrant which features curved lines derived from the stereographic projection of the astrolabe including azimuth lines, zodiac lines and a horizon line. This complex instrument can be used for numerous astronomical calculations.

Label: astronomical compendium
Scope Note: The term should be multiple-keyworded with individual instrument names.

Label: audio/visual equipment
Scope Note: This category includes objects for mechanically recording, transmitting or receiving sound or images, and associated equipment.

Label: aurignacian blade
Scope Note: Broad blade with scalar retouch on one or both edges. The distal end may be variously shaped but is often retouched to a pointed of narrow rounded form.

Label: automaton
Scope Note: The should be entered as an additional Object Name when applied to objects other than clocks and watches, e.g. figures, toys, etc.

Label: award
Scope Note: The term refers specifically for East Asian objects that serve both as money and as medals.

Label: axe money
Scope Note: Copper axe-head shaped item of currency.

Label: axle
Scope Note: The term is restricted to vehicles.

Label: back-plate
Scope Note: This term is restricted to armour. For figure backplates, etc. the term BACKPLATE should be used instead.

Label: back-rest
Scope Note: If the term refers to part of another object, the name of that object should be used instead.

Label: backed blade
Scope Note: Blade with more or less abrupt marginal retouch along all or part of one edge, above the butt. The opposite edge is often unmodified.

Label: backed bladelet
Scope Note: Bladelet with more or less abrupt marginal retouch along all or part of one edge above the butt. The opposite edge is often unmodified.

Label: backed knife
Scope Note: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a stone blade or flake, one edge blunted, the opposite end used as a knife.

Label: backplate
Scope Note: The term should be used for figure backplates, lamp backplates, etc. For armour, the term BACK-PLATE should be used instead.

Label: badge
Scope Note: If in the form of another object, eg. a staff, the term should be multiple-keyworded with the appropriate object name.

Label: baijiasuo
Scope Note: Chinese term for a lucky charm in the shape of a lock, placed around a child's neck as a pendant to bring good luck and protection. Baijiasuo translates literally as '[blessed by] 100 families lock'.

Label: bakhnuq
Scope Note: The term refers to a woman's head-shawl. In Tunisia it is generally rectangular and covers the head and face.

Label: bale-mark
Scope Note: See also the field for Inscription Type.

Label: ball
Scope Note: This term is used for ball-shaped artefacts and has a specific archaeological meaning for the Department of Prehistory and Europe. See also CRYSTAL BALL and GAME-BALL.

Label: ballista bolt
Scope Note: A large bolt or arrow fired from a ballista

Label: bamboo tally
Scope Note: The term refers to a form of token money in China. Long narrow strips of bamboo with inscriptions (usually giving the name of the issuer and the value of the tally, and sometimes also a serial number and instructions for use).

Label: band
Scope Note: Use a Narrow Term if more appropriate. See also 'artefact'.

Label: bandana
Scope Note: A square or rectangular piece of cloth used to cover the head or tied around the neck for protective or decorative purposes.

Label: bangle
Scope Note: See also armlet, arm-band, arm-ring, bracelet and wrist-ornament.

Label: banner-stone
Scope Note: In the context of the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' North America collections, the term refers to an object which has religious and ceremonial associations.

Label: barb
Scope Note: If known, the name of the whole object should be used instead (e.g. arrow).

Label: barbed point
Scope Note: The term refers to an Upper Palaeolithic and Mesolithic bone, antler or ivory projectile tip with barbs on one or both sides. If the barbed point is a spear tip or harpoon tip, enter 'spear' or 'harpoon' as additional Object Names.

Label: baren
Scope Note: The term refers to an object used in Japanese woodblock printing.

Label: bark roll
Scope Note: The term refers to a tightly wound roll of bark which may have served as a net float or as a means of storing the material to be used for making containers or distilling resin.

Label: barkcloth sample
Scope Note: Barkcloth (bark cloth) is beaten or felted bark. The Object Name barkcloth should be only be entered if the object is a piece of barkcloth with no known use, e.g. a sample. If the object is, e.g. an apron, that term is the Object Name. The term barkcloth is always recorded in the Description. The Material is bark or its Narrow Terms.

Label: barrel bar
Scope Note: A component of a watch movement which is screwed to the movement back-plate to provide bearing for the barrel arbor. Often inscribed with a name and place.

Label: barrow
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the context of transport.

Label: batakari cap
Scope Note: Amuletic cap from Ghana.

Label: bath
Scope Note: Use bath-tub for the specific object of that name.

Label: bead
Scope Note: Some departments may wish to exclude the term BEAD from a retrieval on JEWELLERY used as a Broad Term. Search also under 'bead' (Description) or 'beadwork' (Technique) for beads which are part of other objects, rather than objects in their own right.

Label: bead-net
Scope Note: In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the term refers to a covering placed over the bandaged mummy for decorative or amuletic purposes.

Label: beam
Scope Note: When the object is part of a loom, use the term LOOM.

Label: beard
Scope Note: The term refers to false or ornamental beards.

Label: beater
Scope Note: Where the context is weaving, see the Narrow Terms of WEAVING EQUIPMENT.

Label: beating-board
Scope Note: The term refers to a board on which e.g. bark is beaten to produce barkcloth.

Label: beehive-cover
Scope Note: The term refers to a round object, made of ceramic polychrome ware, decorated with various subjects and motifs.

Label: bell
Scope Note: Some departments may wish to exclude the term BELL from a retrieval on MUSICAL INSTRUMENT used as a Broad Term.

Label: bell yoke
Scope Note: The term refers to a yoke for suspending a bell (not carrying).

Label: belly amphora
Scope Note: For specific types, e.g. Type A, see the Type Series field.

Label: belt ladle
Scope Note: The term refers to a ladle with a handle for attaching to a belt.

Label: belt-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Object records with Object Name BELT or its Narrow Terms should also be consulted.

Label: belum
Scope Note: A likeness of a disease-causing spirit, used to entice the spirit out of a human body and contain it. Of Sarawak (East Malaysia).

Label: betel equipment
Scope Note: This term is used to gather up anything used to prepare or serve betel.

Label: bezel
Scope Note: The name of the whole object should be entered, if known.

Label: bi
Scope Note: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a flat jade disc for ritual use.

Label: biberon
Scope Note: This term does not refer to a baby's feeding vessel; see BABY-FEEDER.

Label: bifacially retouched blade
Scope Note: Blade with retouch alternately on the dorsal surface of one edge and the ventral surface of the other.

Label: bifacially retouched flake
Scope Note: Flake with retouch alternately on the dorsal surface of one edge and the ventral surface of the other.

Label: bill
Scope Note: The term refers to a weapon, and not a bill of sale.

Label: binding
Scope Note: The term refers to a type of fastening, and should only be used if the object is found in isolation; otherwise the name of whole object should be used instead.

Label: bird-call
Scope Note: Where appropriate, enter the term WHISTLE as well.

Label: bird-pot
Scope Note: The term refers to a pot in which birds nest.

Label: birille
Scope Note: Glass flask used for tej, Ethiopian honey wine.

Label: blade
Scope Note: The term refers to two quite distinct types of objects. The first, more general meaning, is a component of a tool, implement or weapon. Where known, the name of the whole object should be used instead. In stone artefact terminology a blade is a removal struck from a core deliberately prepared so that the detachments have more or less parallel edges and are at least twice as long as they are wide.

Label: bladelet
Scope Note: In stone artefact terminology a blade is a removal struck from a core deliberately prepared so that the detachments have more or less parallel edges and are at least twice as long as they are wide. A bladelet is smaller than a blade: usually less than 30mm but not more than 50mm long and less than 12mm wide.

Label: blanket band
Scope Note: The term refers to a textile from the Plains tribes of North America which has the form of long beaded hide strips interspersed with roundels. It was used to securely wrap the blankets of Plains peoples while they were on the move.

Label: block
Scope Note: A more specific term should be used if possible.

Label: blockbook
Scope Note: The term refers to a book consisting of full-page woodcuts, usually 15thC.

Label: bloom
Scope Note: Metal waste from casting or working

Label: blow-tube
Scope Note: The term refers to an object used for blowing air to maintain fires; it is not a weapon.

Label: boat-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Object records with the Object Name BOAT or its Narrow Terms should also be consulted.

Label: bog body
Scope Note: Bog body is a term that describes any human remains found in a bog. The cold, acidic conditions of a bog, the lack of oxygen, and the effects of decaying Sphagnum mosses, mean that human remains from bogs are often very well-preserved.

Label: boghdad
Scope Note: The term refers to a talismanic pendant from North Africa, the Sahara and sub-Saharan Africa.

Label: bolo tie
Scope Note: The term refers to the official tie of Arizona, USA, invented during the 1950s.

Label: bolt
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the 'nut and bolt' context. If the object is from a cross-bow, use QUARREL; if from a lock, use LOCK; and if a DRAW-BOLT, use that term.

Label: bonang
Scope Note: The term refers to the entire instrument, comprising a frame and kettle gongs used in gamelan.

Label: bonbonnière
Scope Note: The term refers to a small fancy box to hold sweets.

Label: book
Scope Note: This term should be used for entire books and also for pages extracted from them, apart from: book-illustrations, colophons, frontispieces ad title-pages which have their own Object Names.

Label: book of prints
Scope Note: The term refers to a group of related prints bound together as a presentation or gift volume, without text; usually from the end of the 18thC to mid-19thC.

Label: book-case
Scope Note: The term does not refer to furniture.

Label: book-decoration
Scope Note: The term should not be used for the Department of Prints and Drawings; BOOK-ILLUSTRATION should be used instead.

Label: book-illustration
Scope Note: For the Department of Prints and Drawings, the term is entered as an Object Name for prints extracted from books (or proofs for illustrations), including head-pieces, tail-pieces, vignettes and other book decorations (apart from frontispieces and title-pages which are terms in their own right, under the Broad Term 'book-illustration'.). For Japanese woodblock printed illustrated books, the term is entered for a printed page extracted from an illustrated book. See also the Object Name 'illustrated book'. For vignettes on papyri, check the Description field, as these are not recorded as Object Name 'book-illustration', but only as 'papyrus'.

Label: book-mount
Scope Note: The term includes exterior book-ornaments.

Label: borer
Scope Note: A more specific term should be used if possible.

Label: boss
Scope Note: The name of the whole object should be used, if known.

Label: bosu
Scope Note: Lime-spatula made of whale bone or turtle shell.

Label: bow
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the context of weapons. See also MUSICAL BOW for music, and BOW-STRING for unidentified bow-strings.

Label: bow-string
Scope Note: If the term refers to a MUSICAL BOW, use that term. If from a weapon, use BOW.

Label: bowl-stand
Scope Note: The term refers to a stand for a bowl. When it is both a BOWL and a STAND, enter both terms.

Label: bracelet
Scope Note: Bracelets can be worn on the wrist or arm. The term 'wrist-ornament' has BT: 'arm-ornament' so records for bracelets can be searched for under either BT as well as under 'bracelet'.

Label: bracteate
Scope Note: For objects described as 'bracteates'. See also BRACTEATE COIN, BRACTEATE DISC, and BRACTEATE PENDANT.

Label: bradawl
Scope Note: The term is restricted to carpentry.

Label: brail
Scope Note: The term refers to a girdle for confining a hawk's wings.

Label: breakfast-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'breakfast-set'.

Label: breast-band
Scope Note: The term is restricted to personal ornaments. If more appropriate, HARNESS should be used instead.

Label: bride-price
Scope Note: The term should be multiple-keyworded with other object names, as appropriate, e.g. spear.

Label: bridge-money
Scope Note: The term refers to money made of bronze, associated with bronze spade-money and knife-money of ancient China.

Label: briquetage
Scope Note: A collective name for the pans and fire bars used in the making of salt through evaporation

Label: broadside
Scope Note: The term refers to single sheet with letterpress, most of those in the British Museum have images. Includes slip broadsides.

Label: brockage
Scope Note: The term refers to a coin which has been struck while a previous coin adhered to the striking die, so that a negative impression of one side is imprinted onto the coin.

Label: brooch
Scope Note: As a rule, the Narrow Terms of BROOCH have been used for the collections in the Department of Prehistory and Europe. See also under FIBULA for the Department of Greece and Rome.

Label: brush
Scope Note: If the object is a HAIR-BRUSH, use that term.

Label: brush-hanger
Scope Note: The term refers to a hanging stand for writing and painting brushes in a Korean scholar's studio.

Label: brush-shaper
Scope Note: The term refers to an object used to shape the tip of a brush and to remove excess water or ink.

Label: buckle-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Object records with the Object Name BUCKLE or its Narrow Terms should also be consulted.

Label: burin busque
Scope Note: Dihedral burin on which the transverse part is formed by several burin facets which are usually convex in profile and stopped by a retouched notch. Characteristic of the Aurignacian.

Label: burin on a backed blade
Scope Note: Burin made on blades or bladelets with abrupt backing retouch. The backing is used to provide the striking platform for the burin removal. Characteristic of Epi-Palaeolithic assemblages in North Africa.

Label: burin on a break
Scope Note: Blade or flake on which a break has been used as the striking platform from which a burin spall has been removed, perpendicular or slightly oblique to the axis of the break.

Label: burin on retouched truncation
Scope Note: Burin made on an abrupt retouched truncation which is straight and oblique to the axis of the piece.

Label: burner
Scope Note: If the object is part of a SMOKING-PIPE, use that term.

Label: burqa
Scope Note: See also veil and its Narrow Terms.

Label: byblos point
Scope Note: Tanged point found in Neolithic assemblages in the Near East fashioned on a blade. It is characterised by a tang that is generally not much narrower than the body and which is off-set from the body by an angle of more than 90 degrees (usually greater than 120). The tang tends to be retouched (often through pressure flaking) whilst the body and the point tend to be sparsely worked.

Label: byobu
Scope Note: A folding screen.

Label: cabinet card
Scope Note: The term refers to photograph mounted on card, similar to, but larger than, a carte-de-visite. Despite the similarity, the cabinet format was used for landscape and other views before it was adopted for portraiture.

Label: calender
Scope Note: The term is not restricted to machines.

Label: calipers
Scope Note: The term is restricted to measures.

Label: calligraphy
Scope Note: Records for such objects should, where appropriate, include an additional Object Name, such as 'scroll', etc. and in all cases, the Subject 'calligraphy'. No Technique should be entered for objects which are regarded as 'calligraphy', unless also described as 'painting', etc.

Label: cameo
Scope Note: The term refers to a stone (or shell, glass, glass paste, and other materials) of two or more layers, usually of different colour, which have been carved away to produce an image in relief. However, the term is also used for stones of one colour worked in the same way and for moulded glass or ceramic cameos.

Label: canaanean blade
Scope Note: Blade with a trapezoidal cross-section detached from a unipolar blade core. Characteristic of the early and middle Bronze Age in the Levant.

Label: canoe-fitting
Scope Note: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name CANOE or its Narrow Terms.

Label: canopic urn
Scope Note: This term should not be used for the Department of Ancient Eygpt and the Sudan; see CANOPIC JAR.

Label: cap
Scope Note: The term is restricted to head-gear. See also LID.

Label: cap-hook
Scope Note: A small hook with decorative element on the front and single S-shaped hook soldered onto the back. Often enamelled, studded with gems and pearls, or made in relief in bronze, silver or gold. Worn on the kind of man's black felt hat as worn at the very end of the 15th Century and into the 1530s in Europe.

Label: capital
Scope Note: The term should only be used if the object occurs in isolation; otherwise use COLUMN or PILLAR.

Label: carding-tool
Scope Note: The term refers to a tool used for raising the nap (pile) on the surface of a felted or knitted object. In Tunisia carding tools are used to raise the nap on the surface of chechias (men's skull-caps).

Label: carinated burin
Scope Note: Burin on which the transverse part is formed by several elongated burin facets which are convex in profile and frequently twisted.

Label: carinated end scraper
Scope Note: End scraper made on a thick, domed flake modified by shallow, parallel-sided removals to form a steep scraper front.

Label: carinated scraper
Scope Note: Scraper made on a thick, domed flake modified by steep, invasive, parallel-sided removals.

Label: carriage-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name CARRIAGE or its Narrow Terms.

Label: carrier
Scope Note: This term does cover vessels.

Label: carrying-strap
Scope Note: When the object is a head-strap, use TUMP-LINE.

Label: cart-fitting
Scope Note: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name CART or its Narrow Terms.

Label: carte-de-visite
Scope Note: The term refers to a small portrait photograph mounted on a card.

Label: cartoon
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the context of both frescoes and paintings, and should not be confused with MODERN CARTOON.

Label: cash card
Scope Note: A plastic card used for transactions from a credit based account.

Label: cast
Scope Note: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the Object Name of the original. Any other details of the original should only be entered in the Description and Associated fields.

Label: castor
Scope Note: The term is restricted to furniture.

Label: ceiling-coffer-lid
Scope Note: An additional Object Name of painting or sculpture should be added as appropriate.

Label: chadar
Scope Note: This term refers to a textile garment worn by both men and women in parts of South Asia and the Muslim world. When worn by women it is used to cover the head and shoulders, while men drape it around their shoulders. See also head-shawl and headscarf.

Label: chain mail
Scope Note: Do not use this term in the Department of Prehistory and Europe; use MAIL-ARMOUR.

Label: chalice
Scope Note: The term is generally restricted to a religious context except for in classical Greek and Roman settings where the usage is more defined by form.

Label: chamberlain's key
Scope Note: The term refers to a key which is the emblem of membership of the Royal Household.

Label: chamfered piece
Scope Note: Blade or flake which exhibits an oblique transverse removal at the distal end. They are found amongst Levantine and North African Upper Palaeolithic assemblages.

Label: changgi-board
Scope Note: The term refers to a Korean chess-board.

Label: changgi-piece
Scope Note: The term refers to a Korean chess-piece.

Label: changgi-set
Scope Note: Changgi is Korean chess. The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'changgi-set'.

Label: chapbook
Scope Note: The term refers to a small cheap book made of poor quality paper and sewn together without covers. Chapbooks were sold widely between the late 17th century and early 19h century.

Label: chape
Scope Note: A more specific term should be used if possible, e.g. BELT-FITTING, BUCKLE-FITTING, STRAP-FITTING.

Label: charger
Scope Note: The term is restricted to vessels, but has been used interchangeably with PLATTER. Use PRIMING-FLASK where appropriate.

Label: chariot-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check Object records with Object Name CHARIOT or its Narrow Terms.

Label: chechia
Scope Note: The term refers to a man's woollen skull-cap made in Tunisia.

Label: chemise
Scope Note: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, the term applies to an undershirt.

Label: cheque-card
Scope Note: A plastic card used to guarantee payment of a customer's cheque, up to the specified amount.

Label: cheroot box
Scope Note: The term refers to a container, common in Burma, for storing cheroots. They are frequently decorated with lacquer and in shape often follow that of the cheroot, being tall and thin.

Label: chess-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'chess-set'.

Label: chest panel
Scope Note: The term refers to a square textile, made in Palestine, that is heavily embroidered and made to be sewn onto the front of a dress or shirt.

Label: chokuto
Scope Note: A Japanese term which refers to a straight sword, but similar in construction to the tachi.

Label: chopping tool
Scope Note: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a stone pebble with unifacial or bifacial flaking on one edge.

Label: chopping-block
Scope Note: If the context is culinary, also enter the additional term CULINARY EQUIPMENT.

Label: chopping-board
Scope Note: If the context is culinary, also enter the additional term CULINARY EQUIPMENT.

Label: chronology
Scope Note: In the Department of Prints and Drawings, the term refers to engraved historical and genealogical lineages, e.g. kings, popes, Roman emperors, noble families, etc.

Label: chunk
Scope Note: This is a generic term for a large piece of lithic debitage. It can also be used in glass studies to describe fragment of glass moved in non-ingot form for use in making objects.

Label: cimbataila
Scope Note: The term refers to a musical instrument from Zambia.

Label: cinerary urn
Scope Note: This term has been used interchangeably with FUNERARY URN in some departmental records.

Label: circlet
Scope Note: This term refers to head-gear.

Label: circular end scraper
Scope Note: End scraper on a circular flake with retouch around the entire circumference.

Label: clapper
Scope Note: If part of bell, use BELL. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, double-key with DANCING EQUIPMENT and/or RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT if appropriate.

Label: clay pellet
Scope Note: If referring to a type of ammunition, use PELLET.

Label: cleat
Scope Note: This term is restricted to cleats from boats.

Label: climbing-ring
Scope Note: The term refers to an object used for tree-climbing.

Label: clinker
Scope Note: The term refers to ash and partially fused residues from a coal fired furnace or fire.

Label: cloth
Scope Note: This term has been used interchangeably with TEXTILE in the documentation.

Label: clovis point
Scope Note: Projectile point characterised by tapering parallel-slightly convex edges and concave base; both faces are entirely modified by flat, sub-parallel retouch. The points are thinned by the removal of a flake along the long axis from the base on both faces. These 'flutes' vary in length and enabled hafting. Clovis points are specific to the earliest settlers in North America.

Label: cockspur
Scope Note: If the object is KILN-FURNITURE, use that term.

Label: coffee-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'coffee-set'.

Label: coffin-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Check also Object records with 'coffin' and its Narrow Terms.

Label: coif
Scope Note: Cap, often with a black veil, that covers the hair; used in Tunisia.

Label: coin pendant
Scope Note: The term covers two types of object: either a coin perforated and strung onto a necklace, collar or garment, or suspended through an added suspension loop or bead; or, a pendant set with a coin in a decorative frame.

Label: coin plate
Scope Note: This is used to make clay coin-moulds.

Label: coin strip
Scope Note: Some coins were cast in strips prior to being struck and then separated.

Label: coin tester
Scope Note: This is a device with slots to check that coins are of the correct thickness.

Label: coin-sword
Scope Note: A form of talisman used in southern China to drive away evil. Made from brass cash coins attached to an iron rod using lucky red string.

Label: colander
Scope Note: It is assumed that colanders are used for culinary purposes.

Label: collage
Scope Note: An image made by pasting pieces of paper, or similar material (usually cut out), to a backing.

Label: collar
Scope Note: This term should only be used when it refers to a neck ornament. When the object is part of a garment, the name of the garment should be used instead.

Label: colophon
Scope Note: This refers to a page in a book giiving details of publication.

Label: colouring-book
Scope Note: Use for commercially produced colouring books for children.

Label: comb
Scope Note: The term has generally been used in the sense of 'hair-comb' but this may not be the case for all examples. See Related terms for other types of comb.

Label: comb-case
Scope Note: The term is restricted to cases for hair-combs.

Label: compass
Scope Note: This term is restricted to the instrument used in orientation. See also COMPASSES.

Label: compressor
Scope Note: An elongated stone, bone or antler tool used to detach or retouch flakes and blades by pressure. The removals are pressed off rather than struck off with a percussive hammer action. Compressors may also be used to rub down and thereby adjust the edge of a striking plaform. The working end is usually blunted/rounded by use. These tools are common in the later Upper Palaeolithic.

Label: conch
Scope Note: If the object is a TRUMPET, use that term.

Label: condiment-bowl
Scope Note: Probably used for sauces, but may have been used for salt or spices. See also the terms 'cruet-set' and 'condiment-dish'.

Label: condiment-dish
Scope Note: Probably used for sauces, but may have been used for salt or spices. See also the terms 'cruet-set' and 'condiment-bowl'.

Label: conical cup
Scope Note: Minoan cup, conical in shape, usually with a flat base. Made in large quantities.

Label: console
Scope Note: The term is restricted to architecture.

Label: container-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check object records with CONTAINER or its Narrow Terms.

Label: contorniate
Scope Note: Coin-like token or medallion produced in the 4th and 5th century AD, with a distinctive raised rim. The function of this type of object is uncertain, but they often depict subjects related to public spectacles and games. Earlier emperors and other historical figures are sometimes portrayed on the obverse.

Label: cooking-implement
Scope Note: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: copper
Scope Note: The term refers to a ceremonial symbol of wealth, and should only be used for the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' North American collections.

Label: coprolite
Scope Note: The term refers to preserved or fossilised faeces of an animal or human.

Label: cordophone
Scope Note: The term should be used for a stringed musical instrument when a more specific term is not available. It has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: core
Scope Note: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to the residual objects from which stone tools were made.

Label: core rejuvenation flake
Scope Note: If the striking platform on a core has become unusable or exhausted further removals may become impossible and to continue working it is necessary to restore it by the removal of a rejuvenation flake. Such flakes are struck from the face of the core to remove the old platform. They have a tabular form with steep edges formed by remnants of the scars left by the detachment of blades or bladelets around the core face.

Label: core tablet
Scope Note: Face of a blade or bladelet core detached as a flake in process of rejuvenation.

Label: core trimming flake
Scope Note: Flake removed from the face of a core enable the removal of blades to continue.

Label: corn-bin
Scope Note: If the object is ceramic, the term STORAGE-VESSEL should also be entered as an Object Name in the Object record.

Label: cornet
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the Department of the Middle East and does not refer to a musical instrument.

Label: coronet
Scope Note: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, the term may refer to a head-band or head-dress.

Label: corslet
Scope Note: The term is restricted to armour.

Label: cosmetic-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'cosmetic-set'.

Label: cosmetic-stick
Scope Note: The term refers to the applicator.

Label: costume print
Scope Note: From the 16th century onwards, series of costume prints were produced showing figures in the dress of different nations and classes. Fashion prints, or plates, develop out of these, but their purpose was to show the latest in fashion. They were commonly published in monthly or weekly series.

Label: costume roundel
Scope Note: The term refers to a circular costume accessory.

Label: costume-fitting
Scope Note: The term is restricted to objects which are intended to be attached to costume, and should only be used when such objects occur in isolation. Check also Object records with COSTUME or its Narrow Terms.

Label: counter
Scope Note: See also GAME-COUNTER and GAME-PIECE.

Label: counter-tray
Scope Note: Tray with compartment(s) for holding game counters.

Label: counterpoise
Scope Note: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, when available.

Label: counterproof
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the counterproof is taken from a print.

Label: counting board
Scope Note: This is a board with a grid of holes, for counting coins.

Label: cover
Scope Note: Where more appropriate, the term LID should be used. For the Department of Prints and Drawings, this term includes book-jackets, magazine-covers, portfolio-covers, etc., and should not be multiple-keyworded with BOOK-ILLUSTRATION. See also MUSIC-COVER.

Label: covered cup
Scope Note: This refers to a specific type of cup which has an integral cover, with a hole for drinking.

Label: cowrie money
Scope Note: Cowrie is a recognised term for a type of currency, ie. cowrie shells.

Label: cream pot
Scope Note: The term refers to a Meissen porcelain shape.

Label: credit card
Scope Note: A plastic card used for transactions from a credit based account.

Label: crescent
Scope Note: Bladelet with an evenly curved, convex backed edge formed by direct abrupt retouch. Crescents occur in the Late Stone Age throughout Africa and continue in use into the Neolithic, whilst in the Levant they are commonly found in Epi-palaeolithic assemblages. They are also known as lunates and segments.

Label: crested blade
Scope Note: Blade with removal scars forming a ridge along the mid-line of the dorsal surface and a triangualr cross-section. The ridge is usually formed by bi-directional flaking or uni-directional removals from a natural surface. Crested blades are diagnostic of the early stage of core preparation during which guide ridges must be established to enable the detachment of long, narrow blanks to be made into tools.

Label: crested bladelet
Scope Note: Bladelet with removal scars forming a ridge along the mid-line of the dorsal surface and a triangular cross-section. The ridge is usually formed by bi-directional flaking or uni-directional removals from a natural surface. Crested bladelets are diagnostic of the early stages of bladelet core preparation during which guide ridges must be established to enable the detachment of narrow blanks to be used to make bladelet tools.

Label: crested flake
Scope Note: Flake with removal scars forming a ridge along the mid-line of the dorsal surface and a triangular cross-section. The ridge is usually formed by bi-directional flaking or uni-directional removals from a natural surface. Crested flakes are diagnostic of the early stages of blade/bladelet core preparation during which guide ridges must be established to enable the detachment of narrow blanks to be used to make blade/bladelet tools.

Label: creswell point
Scope Note: Point with angle on the backed edge formed by convergence of backing with an oblique retouched truncation. The edge opposite the backing forms a distal point where it converges with the truncation. The butt is modified to form a proximal point and backing may continue a short distance up the otherwise unmodified edge.

Label: crooked knife
Scope Note: The term refers to a knife with a blade set at a sharp angle to the handle. Commonly used by the First Peoples of Sub-Arctic and northeastern North America.

Label: cross
Scope Note: If Christ is depicted, the term CRUCIFIX should be used instead of CROSS, although this practice has not always been followed.

Label: cross-bow fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also Object records with Object Name 'cross-bow'.

Label: crucifix
Scope Note: The term is restricted to crosses bearing the figure of Christ; otherwise use the term CROSS. This practice has not been followed in all cases, and retrievals should be made under both terms.

Label: cruet
Scope Note: The term originally referred to a small bottle or vial for liquids, now used to refer to vessels for vinegar, oil, etc. for the table, with a stopper. If the cruet is a bottle, also enter that term as an Object Name. See also the terms 'cruet-set', 'condiment-dish' and 'condiment-bowl'.

Label: cruet ecclesiastical
Scope Note: The term refers to a small vessel for wine or water for celebrating the Eucharist, or for holy water for other uses.

Label: cruet-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component, e.g. 'cruet', 'cruet-stand', mustard-pot', 'pepper-pot', 'salt-shaker', should be entered as well as the term 'cruet-set'.

Label: cruet-stand
Scope Note: See also the term 'cruet-set'.

Label: cuauhxicalli
Scope Note: 'Eagle vessel'.

Label: cuff
Scope Note: The term is restricted to wrist ornaments. If from a GARMENT, that term or a specific garment name (e.g. SHIRT) should be used instead.

Label: culinary equipment
Scope Note: The term refers to objects used in cooking and food preparation. See also VESSEL and its Narrow Terms.

Label: cup-kantharos
Scope Note: This is a hybrid between a cup and a kantharos.

Label: cup-skyphos
Scope Note: This is a hybrid betwen a cup and a skyphos.

Label: cupping-glass
Scope Note: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name, if appropriate.

Label: cupping-horn
Scope Note: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name, if appropriate.

Label: cupping-vessel
Scope Note: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be as an additional Object Name, if appropriate.

Label: currency
Scope Note: This category includes issued currency and non-issued media of exchange. It should be multiple-keyworded with other Object Names, if appropriate.

Label: curtain-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. Also check Object records with CURTAIN or its Narrow Terms.

Label: curved backed blade
Scope Note: Blade with direct steep backing retouch beginning above the butt on one edge. The opposite edge is unmodified. The curved backed edge may be convex or concave but never C-shaped as on a crescent.

Label: curved backed bladelet
Scope Note: Blade or bladelet modified by steep, direct backing retouch on one side and an unmodified edge opposite. The curve of the modified edge may be convex or concave.

Label: curved ended blade
Scope Note: Blade or bladelet on which the curved distal end has been formed by direct abrupt - semi abrupt retouch. The curvature of the retouch and continuity of the edge distinguishes this tool type from a distal truncation.

Label: cushion seal
Scope Note: The term refers to rectanglar shaped seals produced in Middle to Bronze Age Crete.

Label: cushion-stone
Scope Note: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe the term refers to a cuboid or sub-cuboid stone with one or more faces ground, perhaps with traces of rubbing or polishing from use; known in Bronze Age contexts.

Label: cutlery
Scope Note: See also Object records for KNIFE, FORK and SPOON, since a large number are probably items of cutlery, but have not been identified as such.

Label: cylinder
Scope Note: This term is restricted to tablets. For cylinder-shaped objects, use ARTEFACT, or a more specific Object Name such as TUBE, etc.

Label: daisho
Scope Note: A Japanese term which refers to a pair of swords in matching fittings worn together: dai- being the long sword, and sho- being the shorter companion sword. Only the samurai were permitted to wear them during the Edo period.

Label: dala
Scope Note: Personal ornament usually worn on the head comprising a shell-disk with an overlay of fretted turtle-shell secured by a hole in the centre, as made in Solomon Islands.

Label: debit card
Scope Note: A plastic card used for direct transactions from cleared funds in an account.

Label: debitage
Scope Note: Waste flakes and cores produced in the manufacture of stone implements.

Label: decanter
Scope Note: In the Department of the Middle East this term may apply to pottery vessels.

Label: decorated antler
Scope Note: Section of antler used to support engraved drawings of animals and/or incised patterns. Decorated antlers are well known with the art of the Upper Palaeolithic and also occur occasionally in Mesolithic and Neolithic contexts.

Label: decorated bone
Scope Note: Bone decorated with engraved or low relief animal figures or patterns. Upper Palaeolithic.

Label: decorated gourd
Scope Note: See also the Materials term GOURD.

Label: decorated paper
Scope Note: The term should be used for items such as marbled paper, etc.

Label: dedicatory cone
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the Department of the Middle East, and refers to an inscribed cone inserted between bricks of buildings.

Label: denticulate
Scope Note: This term refers to a stone flake or blade with a denticulated and retouched edge.

Label: dibble
Scope Note: The term should only be used for planting equipment.

Label: dice
Scope Note: Use dice for the game-piece; see also die.

Label: die
Scope Note: The term should not be used in the context of games or gaming; see also DICE.

Label: dihedral burin
Scope Note: Blade or flake which has a small edge formed by the intersection of two or more burin facets.

Label: dilly bag
Scope Note: Food storage and preparation bag, used by indigenous Australian peoples.

Label: dinner-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'dinner-set'.

Label: diptych
Scope Note: The term RELIGIOUS/RITUAL EQUIPMENT should be entered as an additional Object Name, if appropriate. See also DIPTYCH PRINT.

Label: disc bead
Scope Note: The term refers to a flat bead, made using the lost wax method of casting from precious metal, and worn as part of composite necklaces, bracelets and anklets by the Akan-speaking peoples of Ghana and the Baule of Côte D’Ivoire. It should be added as an additional Object Name to the item it is part of, e.g. 'necklace', where known.

Label: docket
Scope Note: ME - for clay cuneiform examples, also enter TABLET.

Label: document
Scope Note: The term refers to documents whether made of paper, clay, etc.

Label: dolium
Scope Note: In the Department of Greece and Rome this term refers to a large storage-jar.

Label: doll
Scope Note: If the object functions as a TOY, that term should be entered as an additional Object Name.

Label: domino-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'domino-set'.

Label: door
Scope Note: It is assumed that the term refers to architecture; if from furniture, a more appropriate term should be used instead.

Label: door-fitting
Scope Note: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Check also records with Object Name DOOR.

Label: double bevel base point
Scope Note: Upper Palaeolithic point/projectile tip made from bone, antler or ivory which first appear during the Aurignacian but are more frequent in the Middle & Late Magdalenian. Circular in cross-section, the edges are straight tapering slightly to a point at one end and the base is thinned by cutting a flat-slightly concave longitudinal facet (bevel) on two sides. The bevelled end may be slightly pointed, rounded or straight. The bevels may be marked by diagonal, horizontal or longitudinal striations.

Label: double end scraper
Scope Note: Blade or flake modified by retouch forming a more or less rounded front at both the proximal and distal ends.

Label: double side scraper
Scope Note: Flake modified by retouch on opposite edges. The retouch is usually scalar, marginal-semi-invasive forming straight, convex or concave shape. The retouched edges do not converge and are not connected by retouch across the distal end.

Label: double-strike
Scope Note: The term refers to a coin which has been struck more than once and has moved in the die in between strikings so that part of the design is visible twice or more.

Label: dowel
Scope Note: Use the name of the whole object when appropriate.

Label: draft
Scope Note: This refers to notes recording money drawn from a bank account.

Label: drawing
Scope Note: P&D watercolours are regarded as drawings; for that department do not use the term painting.

Label: drawing book
Scope Note: The term refers to a compilation of prints, often in outine, used by students of drawing. The term 'sketch-book' is used for a blank book in which drawings are made, and

Label: drawing instrument
Scope Note: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: drawing-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'drawing-set'.

Label: drawplate
Scope Note: A drawplate is a thick steel plate with many holes of reducing diameters through which wire can be drawn (or pulled) sequentially to make it thinner to achieve or produce the wire diameter needed for the particular jewellery components that are required to construct and embellish the finished object. A typical drawplate may have twenty holes which allows a wide range of wire diameters to be made to suit various purposes.

Label: dream catcher
Scope Note: The term refers to a charm, of North American Indian origin, consisting of a wooden or leather hoop with a webbed centre of threads decorated with feathers, beads, etc., and usually hung above a bed to entrap bad dreams.

Label: dress-pin
Scope Note: If the term refers to an object used in making clothing, use PIN and enter the additional term NEEDLEWORK EQUIPMENT.

Label: dressing-tool
Scope Note: For dressing skins, for example.

Label: drill-core
Scope Note: This term refers to core and other waste from vessel-making processes.

Label: drinking-pot
Scope Note: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: drinking-tube
Scope Note: Some drinking-tubes incorporate strainers.

Label: drinking-vessel
Scope Note: See also BEAKER.

Label: drug sample
Scope Note: Do not specify types of drugs in the Object Name field.

Label: drum-brush
Scope Note: Used for playing drums.

Label: duct
Scope Note: If a part of another object, enter the name of that object.

Label: dufour bladelet
Scope Note: Narrow bladelet which often has a curved profile and is modified by either direst or inverse retouch on one edge only or, on both edges by alternate retouch.

Label: dummy watch
Scope Note: The term refers to any form of imitation watch ranging from pewter ‘toy’ watches of the 17th century through pottery and enamel examples from the 18th century worn by women as dummies to pair with real watches, to 20th century chocolate watches and a plastic watch puzzles.

Label: dupatta
Scope Note: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a scarf worn by Muslim women in India, and by Punjabis.

Label: dye sample
Scope Note: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

Label: e-kamban
Scope Note: The term refers to a picture sign-board, often for theatre.

Label: ear-reel
Scope Note: The term refers to a spool-shaped ear-ornament.

Label: eating-bowl
Scope Note: Used for vessels wtih sole function of food consumption

Label: ebauche
Scope Note: Term used to describe a watch movement which could be purchased from a supplier in various states of completion ranging from simple plates, pillars and balance-cock etc to a completely finished watch movement. Generally the ebauches were supplied with unfinished pivots and without any components of the escapement. Ebauches were purchased by "watchmakers" to be finished by skilled watchmakers ready for dialling and casing up for retail.

Label: edge tool
Scope Note: A tool with a cutting or pounding edge made by bifacial retouch

Label: eel-fork
Scope Note: The term is used in the context of fishing.

Label: egoyomi
Scope Note: The term refers to a 'picture' calendar, a type of Japanese woodblock print with calendrical marks hidden in the design.

Label: el-wad point
Scope Note: Bladelets or small blades which display fine minimally invasive retouch along lateral margins to form a point. They are found amongst Levantine Upper Palaeolithic assemblages.

Label: electrotype
Scope Note: Strictly speaking, the term refers to an exact metallic copy usually made as a one-off from a mould of an original by an electrochemical process (generally referred to as electroforming), a basic plating process aided by an electrical source, in which metal (usually copper) ions migrate through an electrolytic solution and are 'deposited' into a mould on which the ions gradually build to form the shape and detail of the original. However, the use of the term in the British Museum records is broadened to include any metal copy (ie. not only the one-off copy) of the original, produced by this process. The term 'electrotype' is entered as an Object Name as well as the Object Name of the original, and the term 'electroformed' is entered in the Technique field.

Label: embroidery sample
Scope Note: If part of another object, also enter the name of that object.

Label: embroidery-tool
Scope Note: The term refers to a non-specific tool used for embroidery, and has been used as a Broad Term as well.

Label: end scraper
Scope Note: Blade or flake with continuous retouch around one end forming a more or less rounded front.

Label: end scraper on aurignacian blade
Scope Note: End scraper on a large, broad blade characteristic of Aurignacian technology. One or both edges of the blade may also carry scalar retouch.

Label: end scraper on blade
Scope Note: Blade which displays retouch confined to the proximal or distal end.

Label: end scraper on flake
Scope Note: End scraper on a wide flake of variable size with a front which sometimes extends all the way around the periphery, excluding the butt which is always unretouched.

Label: end scraper on retouched blade
Scope Note: End scraper on a blade with continuous retouch on one or both edges.

Label: end scraper on retouched flake
Scope Note: End scraper on a blade or flake with retouch on one or both edges

Label: end scraper-burin
Scope Note: Tool combining any type of endscraper with any type of burin on the same flake or blade.

Label: engraved bone/antler
Scope Note: Use for Palaeolithic (mobiliary) art items engraved on bone or antler.

Label: enlarger
Scope Note: The term does not refer to the type used in photography.

Label: envelope
Scope Note: ME - for the clay cases of cuneiform tablets, use the term TABLET-CASE.

Label: eolith
Scope Note: This term refers to a naturally modified flint, which resembles early tools. There are large numbers of them in the Palaeolithic/Mesolithic collections of the Prehistory and Europe Department.

Label: epinetron
Scope Note: In the Department of Greece and Rome this term refers to a thigh-guard used in the preparation of wool.

Label: equation table
Scope Note: Because of the earth’s angle to the sun and its elliptical path round it there is a difference between apparent solar time and mean solar time. An equation table allows an observer to read the apparent solar time on a sundial and then according to the date on the table add or subtract the equation figure to arrive at the mean solar time. Solar Time agrees with Mean Time on April 16th, June 15th, September 1st and December 25th.

Label: equestrian equipment
Scope Note: The term 'equestrian' covers horses, mules, and donkeys. See also under other Narrow Terms of ANIMAL EQUIPMENT, such as SADDLE, etc. and under SPUR.

Label: extra-illustrated book
Scope Note: The term refers to a method of print collecting that involves assembling prints of people, events and places, and binding them into a special copy of a book such that the prints illustrate the text. Texts that were popular with such collectors were the Rev.J.Granger's 'Biographical History of England' (whence the term 'Grangerising' for such collecting) and the Earl of Clarendon's 'History of the Rebellion and Civil Wars in England'.

Label: eye-bead
Scope Note: Glass beads with decoration formed by applied concentric blobs of different colours.

Label: eye-stone
Scope Note: The term refers to an eye made of semi-precious material removed from a statue, often with an inscription on it, used as a bead.

Label: fabricator
Scope Note: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a rod-like flint implement, possibly for making sparks.

Label: faggot
Scope Note: Used for fire-lighting.

Label: fake
Scope Note: The term refers to an object made with a deliberate attempt to deceive. The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword. See also IMITATION.

Label: fan
Scope Note: In the case of fans of the European type, the term 'fan' is used whether or not the fan has been mounted on sticks; the term 'print' or 'drawing' is added as appropriate. The term 'fan-print' is used for Japanese woodblock prints designed for use as fans, but not necessarily mounted on sticks.

Label: fan-print
Scope Note: In the case of fans of the European type, the term 'fan' is used whether or not the fan has been mounted on sticks; the term 'print' or 'drawing' is added as appropriate. The term 'fan-print' is used for Japanese woodblock prints designed for use as fans, but not necessarily mounted on sticks.

Label: fauchard
Scope Note: A single-edged hafted weapon with hook projecting from back of blade.

Label: figure
Scope Note: The term 'figure' is generally used for representations of animate subjects (e.g. 'dancer') and the term 'model' for inanimate ones (e.g. 'amphora').

Label: figure-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name FIGURE or its Narrow Terms.

Label: film still
Scope Note: The term refers to a single shot from a film (or a specially posed photograph of a scene from it) for use in advertising.

Label: financial instrument
Scope Note: This covers all object names relating to banking and paper currency.

Label: finger-ring
Scope Note: See also RING and its Narrow Terms, since some finger-rings may not yet have been identified as such.

Label: finial
Scope Note: This term is restricted to architecture; use TERMINAL for other contexts.

Label: fish-knife
Scope Note: The term is restricted to cutlery. See also the term FISHING-KNIFE.

Label: fishing equipment
Scope Note: This category also includes objects used for fishing crustacea, molluscs, etc. For whaling equipment, including harpoons, see HUNTING EQUIPMENT.

Label: fitting
Scope Note: This term should only be used for unspecified fitting. The names of specific types of fitting should only be used for important collections of such objects, otherwise the most appropriate broader category is entered, e.g. VESSEL-FITTING.

Label: flail
Scope Note: The term is assumed to refer to agriculture. See also RITUAL FLAIL.

Label: flake
Scope Note: In stone artefact terminology a flake is the product detached when a hammer is used to modify another piece or nodule of stone. Many flakes are simply waste products (debitage) produced during knapping; some may subsequently be modified by retouch and are then defined and named as various types of tools.

Label: flenching-tool/implement
Scope Note: The term refers to an object used for cutting-up or flaying whales or seals.

Label: flint
Scope Note: The term is restricted to objects used with a steel to light a fire. For tools made of flint, see TOOL/IMPLEMENT and its Narrow Terms. For miscellaneous samples of flint, use SAMPLE.

Label: flower money
Scope Note: Name of a kind of money used in Burma.

Label: fly-shooter
Scope Note: If the object also functions as a TOY, enter that term as an additional keyword.

Label: food-basket
Scope Note: This has not been used as a BT.

Label: food-stamp
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the tool.

Label: food-tray
Scope Note: This is not a Broad Term.

Label: forgery
Scope Note: The term refers to an object made with a deliberate attempt to deceive. The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword. See also IMITATION.

Label: fossil
Scope Note: A fossil is a preserved remain of a previously living organism (plant or animal). Leaves, cockle shells, bones, wood, coprolites, etc may all be preserved as fossils. They may be preserved or partially preserved as all sorts of different materials, e.g. calcite, pyrite, limonite, amber, etc. If the specific material of which the fossil is composed is not known, then no Material should be entered.

Label: foundation-deposit
Scope Note: This term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of the specific object, if known.

Label: four-sided prism
Scope Note: The term refers to a Minaoan seal.

Label: frieze
Scope Note: This term is under the Broad Term sculpture as well as under architecture, because in most instances the British Museum friezes (or parts) are in relief. For textiles, use WALL-HANGING or another term from the thesaurus.

Label: fringe
Scope Note: This term should only be used when the object from which the fringe came is not known. See also GARMENT and its Narrower Terms.

Label: frontlet
Scope Note: The term refers to harness; for human use, see HEAD-BAND.

Label: funerary cone
Scope Note: Conical objects of fired clay used to create decorative friezes over the entrances to tombs of the New Kingdom, especially at Thebes. The cones were set into the wall in rows to leave the circular blunt end visible, which was stamped with an inscription giving the name and titles of the tomb-owner.

Label: funerary equipment
Scope Note: This Broad Term includes equipment used during the process of embalming.

Label: funerary urn
Scope Note: This term has been used interchangeably with CINERARY URN in some departmental records.

Label: furnishing
Scope Note: Some departments may wish to exclude the term TEMPLE-HANGING from retrievals under FURNISHING or HANGING.

Label: furniture-fitting
Scope Note: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Also check records with Object Name FURNITURE or its NTs.

Label: gable-mask
Scope Note: Mask attached to apex of house or storehouse.

Label: game
Scope Note: This term should only be used for unspecified games. See also game-piece and game-board.

Label: game-board
Scope Note: For searches for board games, see also the Narrow Terms of game-piece.

Label: gamelan
Scope Note: The term is used to refer to the set of instruments and associated equipment used in Indonesian music and ritual. If the Object Name is not a Narrow Term of 'gamelan', that term should be added as an additional Object Name.

Label: games/sporting equipment
Scope Note: The category includes objects used in sports, games and gaming (gambling).

Label: gaming-board
Scope Note: The term should be used in the context of gambling.

Label: gaming-charm
Scope Note: It is not clear whether the term refers to a charm or a gaming-piece.

Label: gaming-piece
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the context of gambling.

Label: garland
Scope Note: This term is restricted to Personal Ornament; see also WREATH and FUNERARY WREATH.

Label: garment
Scope Note: Some terms regarded as garments under certain classification systems have been entered in the PERSONAL ACCESSORY hierarchy.

Label: garniture
Scope Note: A garniture is a set of matching vessels of uneven number, usually varying from five to nine pieces, made for display on the mantelpiece, on brackets and cornices of walls, and in cupboards and cabinets of European houses (Harrison-Hall and Krahl 1994).

Label: gbetu
Scope Note: The term refers to a ritual mask of the Gola people.

Label: ge ganafi
Scope Note: Ethiopian trousers.

Label: gem
Scope Note: The term has been used in some records to refer to a gemstone which has been worked. The more specific terms cameo and intaglio are used in preference to gem as Object Names, but such objects have traditionally been published as gems in the British Museum catalogues. See also Material gemstone.

Label: geringsing
Scope Note: Textiles produced using the double ikat technique. Produced in the village of Tenganan Pageringsingan, Bali, Indonesia.

Label: girdle
Scope Note: This term refers to a waist garment, but has the Broad TERM 'belt' as it is so defined in the OED. See also 'corset'. N.B. In the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan, the term 'girdle' refers to a string of beads, shells, etc., sometimes found at the waist in burial contexts. In such cases, the additional term 'jewellery' should be entered as an Object Name.

Label: girdle-hanger
Scope Note: The term refers to a pendant suspended from a woman's girdle or belt, and usually resembling a pair of latchlifter-type keys in Anglo-Saxon regions, or sometimes single discs on the Continent.

Label: glass print
Scope Note: The term refers to a mezzotint pasted to glass, hand-coloured and then framed.

Label: glass slide
Scope Note: The term refers to photographic slides, not microscope slides.

Label: goad
Scope Note: The term is restricted to animal goads.

Label: god stick
Scope Note: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' Oceania collections this term refers to a non-figurative stick symbolising God.

Label: gold-weight
Scope Note: Gold-weights were used to weigh out measures of gold dust in West Africa before the arrival of European traders on the coast in the late fifteenth century. The majority of gold-weights were created by the Akan-speaking communities that lived on the Gold Coast (now modern-day Ghana). They are made using the lost wax casting method from brass (an alloy of copper) and can be abstract or figurative in form.

Label: gorget
Scope Note: The term refers to an armoured throat-piece; where the object is a a personal ornament use NECK-ORNAMENT.

Label: grinding-stone
Scope Note: Tool used for the process of grinding.

Label: grommet
Scope Note: The term refers to a small metal ring used to reinforce an eyelet through which a fastener may be passed. It should only be entered when the object is found in isolation and the object it originated from is unknown.

Label: grooved pebble
Scope Note: The term refers to a pebble or piece of stone usually about 6-10 cm long with a broad, U-shaped groove on the long axis of one or both faces. The inner surface of the groove is smooth but may show some fine longitudinal striations resulting from another material such as wood or sinew being moved back and forth within the channel. Often called arrow or shaft straighteners, grooved stones are not culturally or chronologically diagnostic. They occur in the Late Stone Age and more recent contexts in Southern Africa, in Late Palaeolithic to Early Bronze Age contexts in Europe, as well as being known in Australia and South Asia.

Label: guard
Scope Note: This does not include ARMOUR. See under that term.

Label: gulpash
Scope Note: The term refers to a rose-water sprinkler of disctinctive Indian shape.

Label: gulup te eraz
Scope Note: Ethiopian dress used by older women at weddings to indicate status.

Label: gunnery quadrant
Scope Note: A quadrant used to measure the angle of elevation of guns to calculate firing ranges.

Label: gunpowder sample
Scope Note: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

Label: gunpowder-tester
Scope Note: A device used to test the strength of gunpowder.

Label: gunter quadrant
Scope Note: A specific type of horary quadrant named after Edmund Gunter who proposed this design in 1623. In addition to finding the time of day, this instrument could be used to make several calculations about the position of the Sun throughout the year or determine the times of sunrise and sunset. This popular design also enabled one to tell the time the night, either by measuring the position of prominent stars or by aligning a simple map of the stars on the reverse of the instrument with the orientation of the stars seen above.

Label: habaki
Scope Note: In the Department of Asia this term refers to a collar around the sword blade and above the tang.

Label: habb
Scope Note: Arabic word, variant hubb, meaning water-jar.

Label: hackgold
Scope Note: The term refers to cut-down scraps of gold used as bullion or for recasting. An additional Object Name should be entered if appropriate.

Label: hacksilver
Scope Note: The term is derived from the German word hacksilber and refers to scrap silver used as bullion or melted down for recasting. An additional Object Name should be entered if appropriate.

Label: hana-ire
Scope Note: This term should only be entered when it is specifically used by the maker.

Label: hand-guard
Scope Note: Only enter this term if the hand-guard is found in isolation; otherwise enter the name of the whole object.

Label: handle
Scope Note: Enter the name of the whole object if known.

Label: handscroll
Scope Note: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

Label: hanging scroll
Scope Note: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

Label: hansatsu
Scope Note: The term hansatsu ('clan notes') refers to a type of paper money issued in Japan.

Label: harness-fitting
Scope Note: Only use the term when the object occurs in isolation. Also check records with Object Name HARNESS or its Narrow Terms.

Label: harpago
Scope Note: A Latin term for 'harpagon' (archaic term) which is a grappling-hook.

Label: hasp
Scope Note: Enter the name of the whole object if possible.

Label: head-cover
Scope Note: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: head-piece
Scope Note: When the term refers to animal equipment, use TRAPPINGS or its Narrow Terms. For the Department of Prints and Drawings use the term BOOK-ILLUSTRATION instead.

Label: head-ring
Scope Note: Enter the term if the object is an ornament, but enter LOAD-CARRIER if more appropriate.

Label: head-rope
Scope Note: If more appropriate use TUMP-LINE.

Label: headscarf
Scope Note: See also 'chadar'.

Label: hearth
Scope Note: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas, where the object is used as a FIRE-STICK, use that term.

Label: hell money
Scope Note: The term refers to imitation paper money made specifically in the Chinese world for burning to the ancestors. The act of burning it serves as the means of conveying the value to the other world for use there.

Label: helmet mask
Scope Note: The term refers to a type of mask worn over the head.

Label: helwan point
Scope Note: Tanged point found in Neolithic assemblages in the Near East fashioned on a blade or bladelet, rarely on a flake. It is characterised by one or more pairs of bilateral notches, and a tang which is small in proportion to the body.

Label: hilt
Scope Note: Enter the name of the whole object if known.

Label: hip-wrapper
Scope Note: The term is generic and refers to a a large rectangular textile, usually of cotton, though sometimes of silk, used in South and Southeast Asia as a garment for the lower body.

Label: hobby-horse
Scope Note: If the object also functions as a TOY, enter that term as an additional keyword.

Label: hoe
Scope Note: 'Hoe' is the Maori name for a paddle.

Label: holder
Scope Note: This is a Broad Term mainly for terms incorporating 'holder', as used in curatorial documentation.

Label: hollow-based arrow-head
Scope Note: Stone arrowhead with barbs formed by a retouched notch at the base. The width and depth of the concavity forming the barbed base varies according to blank type, raw material, period and region. The hollow provides the fixing point for the arrow shaft in place of a tang. Hollow based arrowheads are found in the Neolithic of Europe and Africa.

Label: hongbao
Scope Note: The term refers to Chinese red money paper envelopes for children at ceremonies.

Label: hood
Scope Note: The term is restricted to head-gear; see also COVER.

Label: hook
Scope Note: The term FASTENER should be used for clothing and the term HOOK for implements.

Label: hooked tag
Scope Note: The term refers to an Anglo-Saxon dress fitting.

Label: horary quadrant
Scope Note: A quadrant used to measure the height of the Sun in the sky. The time is determined by measuring the position of a bead on a plumb bob against a series of curved equal or unequal hour lines.

Label: hordi harir ge ganafi
Scope Note: Ethiopian trousers

Label: horse-coin
Scope Note: Coin-shaped game-pieces used in the Chinese board-game Da Ma ('Driving the Horses').

Label: horsham point
Scope Note: Type of Mesolithic British flint tool.

Label: house note
Scope Note: The term refers to a category of object produced by banknote printers, showing their security printing techniques. Although not technically a banknote, it has the Broad Term banknote, as anyone searching for the latter would expect to retrieve house note as well.

Label: hsun-gwet
Scope Note: The term refers to a tiered, round-topped vessel for holding offerings.

Label: hta-mein
Scope Note: The term refers to a Burmese women's skirt cloth, a longyi.

Label: hub
Scope Note: Enter the name of the whole object if known.

Label: human remains
Scope Note: The term 'human remains' as an Object Name is only recorded in certain cases for this type of collection. The following rules apply. - Human remains in the form of (or forming part of) objects such as drums, shields, etc., have those Object Names recorded (ie. 'drum', 'shield', etc.). - In cases where such Object Names do not apply, the Narrow Terms of 'human remains' are entered (e.g. 'bog body'). - If neither of these two options apply, the term 'human remains' itself is recorded as an Object Name. 'Human remains' are defined as whole bodies (or parts of bodies), bones, organs and tissue, as well as hair and nails. To retrieve all records for 'human remains' across the database, the term 'human remains' with its Narrow Terms should be searched for in the Materials field, where they are always entered for this type of collection, regardless of the Object Name.

Label: hunting equipment
Scope Note: This includes objects associated with hunting for sport as well as for subsistence. See also FISHING EQUIPMENT, GAMES AND SPORTS and WEAPON categories.

Label: husking-tray
Scope Note: Used in the Department of the Middle East.

Label: hydraulic equipment
Scope Note: The category refers to objects used to convey or direct a water supply. See also IRRIGATION EQUIPMENT.

Label: ibeji
Scope Note: The term refers to a a carved wooden figure made by the Yoruba people as a substitute for a deceased twin.

Label: icon
Scope Note: Any image of a sacred personage or subject in the Orthodox Church, mainly painted on a portable wood panel. Other media can be of textile, leather, metal, glass.

Label: ikupasuy
Scope Note: Ceremonial items which are used by Ainu men when honouring the gods / spirits. They are made of carved wood. Designs include animals and boats as well as geometric patterns. Names used for these articles in the literature on the Ainu include 'mustache stick', 'mustache lifter', libation wand' and 'prayer stick'.

Label: illustrated book
Scope Note: The term refers in the premodern period to Japanese woodblock-printed books, where text and images are created by the same technical process, on the same woodblocks. The term is also used for books in the Western tradition that have a number of pictorial illustrations (not merely a frontispiece or decorative ornaments). See 'book-illustration' for a printed page extracted from an illustrated book; and also 'photobook' and 'artist book'.

Label: imborivungu
Scope Note: Imborivungu belong to the category of akombo (power objects), used by the Tiv people in Nigeria. Imborivungu are related to ancestral cult rituals, and are either for the lineage (or kin group), or the individual.

Label: imitation
Scope Note: The term refers to an object which is generally a copy of a design, technique or style, e.g. coin pendants which are more or less loosely based on coins, or archaeological revival objects which copy antique finds, etc. The Object Name of the original should be entered as an addtional keyword. See also FAKE.

Label: inau
Scope Note: Sacred shaved sticks, they are said to symbolise birds and send prayers on their way to the spirit world.

Label: incense sample
Scope Note: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.

Label: ink sample
Scope Note: Enter the constituents, if known, in the Materials field.
