Scope Note: The term refers to the hilt of any Japanese blade and is entered as an Object Name whether part of a complete assembly or found in isolation. See also 'fuchi-kashira' and 'menuki'.

Label: tumpline
Scope Note: The term refers to a carrying strap that sits across the forehead to help distribute the weight of a object carried on the back.

Label: tunjo
Scope Note: This term is a flat metal anthromorphic votive figure made by the Muisca culture.

Label: turban-hook
Scope Note: The term refers to a hook upon which turbans are hung.

Label: tweezers
Scope Note: If the object has been used in a toilet or cosmetic context, the additional term TOILET/COSMETIC EQUIPMENT should be used instead.

Label: uki-e
Scope Note: The term refers to a perspective picture particularly relating to townscapes or building interiors. The term should be entered both as an Object Name and in the Subject field.

Label: ulu
Scope Note: In the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas the term should only be used for the North America collections; for the Oceania collections the term MAIKA-PIECE should be used instead.

Label: undergarment
Scope Note: The term refers to clothes worn under others, especially next to the skin.

Label: unifacial leaf point
Scope Note: Stone projectile tip modified on one face. These usually have a willow leaf form with straight-slightly convex parallel sides with a rounded butt and pointed tip. These points vary in size and could have been used to tip arrows, darts, spears or lances. They are found in the European Upper Palaeolithic and the Neolithic of Africa and Europe.

Label: uniform
Scope Note: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the names of the individual objects comprising the uniform.

Label: unrecorded
Scope Note: This term should only be used when the documentation does not provide sufficient information to enter an object name.

Label: urinal
Scope Note: The term is restricted to vessels.

Label: usokaeru
Scope Note: Figure of bullfinch sold in some shrines in Japan, kept in homes to absorb lies throughout the year and exchanged for a new bird the following year.

Label: valve
Scope Note: The name of the whole object should be entered instead, if known. If the object is a float-valve, use the term FLOAT-PLUG.

Label: varnish sample
Scope Note: The names of the constituents should be entered in the Materials field.

Label: vehicle-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name VEHICLE or its Narrow Terms.

Label: veil
Scope Note: The term refers here to a piece of cloth,, plain or decorated, worn by women and girls over the head or face, either as part of a hat or head-dress or in order to conceal or protect the face.

Label: vessel-cover
Scope Note: This has been used interchangeably with LID. It is also used for complete covers, e.g. of basketry, for vessels.

Label: vessel-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with the Object Name VESSEL or its Narrow Terms.

Label: vest
Scope Note: The term WAISTCOAT should be used if more appropriate.

Label: vestment
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the ecclesiastical context.

Label: vignette
Scope Note: Only to be used for prints of designs appearing on banknotes when they are not part of a printed note or a proof Term is not used by Prints & Drawings.

Label: visor
Scope Note: If the object is from a HELMET, use that term.

Label: visual representation
Scope Note: This category is intended to encompass mainly two-dimensional objects with images. See also 'communications equipment'.

Label: votive offering
Scope Note: The term should be multiple-keyworded with other Object Names, as appropriate.

Label: wagon-fitting
Scope Note: The term should only be used when the object occurs in isolation. See also records with Object Name WAGON or its Narrow Terms.

Label: waist-band
Scope Note: The term has not been used as a Broad Term for garments worn around the waist.

Label: waist-cloth
Scope Note: This term has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: wall
Scope Note: If the object is a tent-wall, the term TENT should be used instead.

Label: wall cone
Scope Note: This term is used to describe stone or (more commonly) purposefully fired clay cones which were applied as architectural decoration in shrines in Mesopotamia during the second half of the fourth millennium BC. In some cases there is evidence for the flat ends of the cones being painted so that the final compositions had a geometric appearance, perhaps inspired by woven matting. The technique also spread to south-west Iran and the Egyptian delta at the same period. P.R.S. Moorey, 'Ancient Mesopotamian Materials and Industries. The Archaeological Evidence', Oxford: Clarendon Press (1994), pp. 309-310.

Label: wall-ornament
Scope Note: This has not been used as a Broad Term.

Label: wall-pocket
Scope Note: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas this term refers to a North American bag-like container attached to a wall.

Label: wall-scroll
Scope Note: Records for such objects should include an additional Object Name such as 'painting', 'drawing', 'print', 'rubbing' or 'calligraphy', and the corresponding technique in Techniques.

Label: waster
Scope Note: The term should be multiple-keyworded with the name of the object.

Label: watch-fob
Scope Note: The term watch-fob refers to a small medallion or ornament which is attached by a short chain or ribbon to a fob-watch.

Label: watch-paper
Scope Note: The additional Object Names 'print', 'drawing', etc. should be added as appropriate.

Label: watchman's clock
Scope Note: A form of clock which is used to automatically record the presence of a watchman at a particular location at allotted times. The clock is locked to the watchman but is inspected by a supervisor to check that the watchman was on duty.

Label: water-hoist
Scope Note: The term refers to, for example, an Egyptian "shaduf" and Archimedean screw. If used for irrigation, double-key with IRRIGATION EQUIPMENT.

Label: water-pipe
Scope Note: Water-pipes were invented at the beginning of the seventeenth century, either in Iran or India. They are known in Persian as qalyun or qalyan, India as a huqqa or hookah and Arabic as narghileh or shisha; they are also popularly also known as a hubble-bubble pipe.

Label: water-scoop
Scope Note: This term should not be confused with BAILER.

Label: water-vessel
Scope Note: For the Department of Asia see also RELIGIOUS/RITUAL VESSEL.

Label: weather forecaster
Scope Note: An object employed in meteorological predictions.

Label: wedding memorial-card
Scope Note: This is not an invitation, but a card to commemorate the event

Label: wedding-ring
Scope Note: For the Department of Prehistory and Europe, see also POSY-RING.

Label: weight
Scope Note: It is assumed that the term refers to measuring-weights. For objects used for 'weighing-down' see the Related Terms of WEIGHT.

Label: weiqi-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'weiqi-set'.

Label: wheel
Scope Note: A more specific term should be used if possible.

Label: whip-sling
Scope Note: The main use of this object is as a spear or dart-thrower. When the object has been used in the context of games, the term GAME should be entered as an additional keyword.

Label: whistling vessel
Scope Note: Enter a second Object Name, as necssary, for the specific vessel, e.g. vase.

Label: wind-rose
Scope Note: The term refers to a diagram, similar to a compass-rose, except that it indicates the directions (or names) of the winds. There is often (but not always) a detachable wind-vane that can be put in the centre of the wind-rose. An additional Object Name should be entered, such as 'drawing' or 'print', as appropriate.

Label: window
Scope Note: The term should only be used if the object is complete; otherwise enter one of the Narrow Terms.

Label: wine-vessel
Scope Note: For the Department of Asia's Chinese collections, see also RELIGIOUS/RITUAL VESSEL.

Label: wire-gauge
Scope Note: A plate with graded cut-outs around the edge, used for measuring the gauge of wire.

Label: wool-weight
Scope Note: In the Department of Prehistory and Europe this term refers to a 7lb weight used for weighing bales of wool.

Label: wound-plug
Scope Note: The term is restricted to the context of hunting.

Label: wrapping-paper
Scope Note: The additional term DECORATED PAPER should also be entered, if appropriate.

Label: wreath
Scope Note: The term FUNERARY WREATH should be entered instead, if more appropriate. Where the term refers to head-gear use HEAD-BAND, etc.

Label: writing sheet
Scope Note: The term refers to a sheet with a pictorial or ornamental border designed for a child to provide a specimen of handwriting. Such sheets are sometimes referred to as Christmas sheets.

Label: writing-board
Scope Note: The term covers different types of object. One type consists of a wooden board written on in ink, e.g. from Africa. The second type consists of wooden or ivory boards with wax-filled recesses, sometimes hinged together and the ancient Middle Eastern examples represent the beginning of the tradition continued in Egypt and in the Romano-British context, where they are referred to as writing-tablets; see under 'writing-tablet'.

Label: writing-book
Scope Note: The term refers to a handbook of calligraphy.

Label: writing-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'writing-set'.

Label: writing-tablet
Scope Note: These objects have also been referred to as 'writing-boards' in the literature. See also the term 'tablet'. The term 'writing-tablet' is used for tablets with inscriptions, usually made of wood but also sometimes of other materials such as copper alloy, ivory, etc. Where they contain multiple pages, they may be hinged. There are two varieties: 1) stilus-tablets, on which the writing was incised with a pointed stilus into a layer of wax recessed into the wooden tablet. 2) leaf-tablets, which were thin slices of wood inscribed in ink with a pen. The so-called ‘Vindolanda Tablets’ are in fact writing-tablets.

Label: yam stick
Scope Note: For the Department of Africa, Oceania and the Americas' Oceania collections, this term refers to an ornamental stick used in ceremonies.

Label: yaobao
Scope Note: The term refers to a Chinese container for shaking dice.

Label: yoke
Scope Note: The term applies to yokes used by people, rather than animals, as load-carriers. See also yoke (harness) and other yoke entries.

Label: yoke harness
Scope Note: If the object is a LOAD-CARRIER, use that term.

Label: yokohama-e
Scope Note: Images relating to foreigners in the port of Yokohama around 1860; or imagery of foreign countries produced around this time in Japan. Enter 'foreigner' as Subject.

Label: yoni
Scope Note: For the Department of Asia this term refers to an Indian object representing the female generative organ, and often combined with the linga. See also LINGA.

Label: yut-set
Scope Note: The Object Names of each component should be entered as well as the Object Name 'yut-set'.

Label: ?ara
Scope Note: The term refers to a painted ceramic disc, like a pot-lid, used as an icon of the god.
